pros: My colleagues at Wells Fargo were very professional and made my time there the highlight of my banking experience. Prior to the scandal the bank’s leadership outside of consumer banking had much more authority and the banks ability to be competitive was fun and winning meaningful relationships and positively impacting customers was commonplace. After the scandal became the central focus it was a completely different work place for all areas of the bank which 95% of the bank had nothing to do with the account scandal. The former leader of the consumer side of the business and her unquestioned support from the CEO of the bank at that time was the downfall for this organization.
cons: The bank lost its direction after the account scandal broke. No one employee including the CEO (he was in denial) really understood the changes that would be forthcoming once the effects of this fully took effect. The bank no longer was in control of its narrative nor was it capable of communicating to its employees what was going on with its regulatory enforcements that never stopped coming. Being an employee at Wells Fargo is not something I would recommend to anyone in the next few years unless you are looking for mission impossible and your work will never culminate into a feeling of satisfaction. My role was the tip of the spear in helping the bank bring in new customer relationships. As part of the banks effort to appease a multitude of its regulatory issues, the bank set up a number of safety towers or silos (operating separately of one another). This sounds like it was a good idea, but because the leaders of these various silos operated independently of each other and did not communicate it was a complete nightmare to get anything done productive and help create positive outcome. The time it took to board a new relationship is typically many months and not weeks as most banks board new clients. The culture of the bank has become one of fear and uncertainty. By in large there are fewer senior experienced bankers working as they are leaving for other opportunities. By in large, turnover is not occurring in higher salaried enployees despite the dysfunction because they won’t have someone pay them what they make at WF. The higher paid employees typically comprised of senior leadership are under tremendous pressure as their top performers are running over them getting out the door.

review_title: Low paying compared to competitors and satisfaction depends on location
pros:
As a company: 

- holiday pay (if you are scheduled to be off on a holiday, you will get an extra holiday for yourself)
- big company so there are many opportunities (although mostly entry level...explained in cons below) and many locations to choose from
- great rewards for being considered top of your line of business
- regarding the center/office jobs, very flexible if you are a student 
- great company to start with if you are beginning a career in banking 
- if you need to know, and because I know other banks do so, Wells does not do random drug tests or credit checks unless it is required for a role that is tied with regulations (i.e. advisor, mortgage, etc.)
cons:
- your job satisfaction will be very determined on your location and the department you are in. My last job was as a research and remediation analyst but before that, I was a team lead in everyday banking aka customer service aka consumer banking in a call center. Before that, inqas a regular customer service rep. As a team lead, it was the best balance of leading/caring for your team, being busy with different avenues of the business like chat and escalations, etc. As a research analyst in my specific dept, management wasn't the greatest. Again, just too varied on job, so I'll focus more on the company itself for the rest of the cons.
- pay. I am now working at another major bank, and I have realized that Wells Fargo's pay is about 10 to 20% less than its competitors (big banks)
- no appreciation for in-bank experience. If you work in a department, and then get hired in a different department, but it is considered a lateral move, you will make your same pay. That is okay until you find out that if the department decides to have a departmental increase, you will not receive the pay increase since you were not "promoted". This means that a new person who have no prior experience at that level or a new hire to Wells will make more than a person who might have decided to change departments but remained at the same level. Apparently, that is a company policy according to a recruiter before I decided to quit.

job_title: Account Resolution Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The pay and benefits were great and we were allowed a not at all unreasonable amount of PTO, holidays, etc. There was a pay differential if you chose to work later hours as well, and extra pay if you worked holidays. 401k was good and I enjoyed the free savings account that I opened after becoming employed with them. Working in person, the campus on which training took place was really cool and had all kinds of things that made being at work convenient. I could have easily lived in that building if such a thing were allowed. I hope other locations are anything like it.
cons:
Training was simultaneously very thorough and very sink-or-swim at the same time. I felt mostly prepared going into the role but once I was on the floor taking calls I realized quickly how much had been left out. There were a great deal of important job functions that weren't covered in training that I and the others who trained with me had to ask coworkers about. 

Time on the phones and time in general was very micromanaged down to the minute. If you spent too long on a call or too long in wrap it was only a matter of time until someone was on the case about it no matter how reasonable it was or how detailed the notes were. This isn't necessarily true of the company as a whole but in my role with my boss I felt as though my failures were recognized disproportionately to my successes.

At the time that I was working with Wells Fargo the company was in the news a lot for any number of scandals. We were always being emailed about them and briefed on how to respond if certain things came up in conversation, or how to redirect them to a team geared to speak with the media and things like that. It was frustrating having to keep on top of it all, especially when most of it had nothing to do with my role whatsoever.

Lastly, collections for home mortgage was just a distressing job. That isn't Wells Fargo's fault but it's true of the role even so. It was difficult to hear people talk about the massive obstacles in their life getting in the way of them paying their home loan and hearing their distress in being told they're at risk of losing their home if they don't pay, and there's only so much we as employees can do about that. Being unable to help people beyond a certain extent when their only wrongdoing is not having money to live on felt terrible and acknowledging that on the floor felt like an admission of weakness. I felt like "the bad guy" a lot. It wasn't the worst job but I'm glad I don't work there anymore.
